metadata.title: Stability and Aggregation Kinetics of Titania Nanomaterials under Environmentally Realistic Conditions

sections.text:
■ INTRODUCTION TiO2 is a multipurpose material widely used in nanoparticulate form. TiO2 nanoparticles (NPs) are routinely used in products like sun creams, cosmetics, paints, self-cleaning dispersions, textiles, sports equipment, solar cells, and wastewater treatment devices, as well as acting as additives for enhanced oil recovery,1.2 Its unique properties give it an increased demand in different industries but at the same time causes increasing environmental concerns. It is understood that the migration behavior, toxicity, and bioavailability of NPs are governed by their physicochemical properties such as shape, size, surface area, agglomeration state, zeta potential, and surface chemistry.3,4 In the past decade, the aggregation kinetics of different NPs has been extensively investigated.5−10 As TiO2 NPs have the tendency to aggregate and coalesce into big particles, which is undesirable for most of the applications,11 their colloidal stability investigation becomes important.12,13 Most of the physicochemical properties of NPs are related to their behaviors in dispersions including the reactions at the particle−liquid interface.14 To fully evaluate the environmental implications, the mobility and risks of such NPs, the knowledge regarding their interaction with different media constituents, and the aggregation kinetics are essential. Several factors are responsible for NPs aggregation as studied by different scientists.15−18 First, the surface charge of the NPs greatly influences their solubility and hence the stability. Surface charge results in either attractive
(positive−negative interaction) or repulsive (similar charge interactions) energies, which depends on the pH, temperature, and the concentration and type of the electrolyte in the medium. The presence of electrolytes in the medium would alter the stability and agglomeration state of NP dispersions. Second, the concentration of the NP precursors, polymers, surfactants, and the temperature would alter the overall stability of dispersions. Water or other molecules could interact with NPs and alter their crystal structures. Zinc sulfide (ZnS) NP is a good example as reported by Zhang et al. (2003), where 3 nm ZnS NP containing around 700 atoms rearranged their crystal structures after interaction with water to form more ordered bulk structure.19 Guzman and co-workers20 showed a pHzpc (i.e., pH at point of zero charge) dependence of titania NPs while French et al.21 observed the influence of ionic strength (IS), on the aggregation kinetics of 50−60 nm TiO2 agglomerates (with 5 nm primary size) at low IS. Similarly surface charge and zeta-potential have a strong correlation with the aggregation kinetics of ZnO NPs.22 In an interesting study on the aggregation kinetics,23 Suwannee river fulvic acid (SRFA)-stabilized TiO2 NPs showed strong stability at varying

IS under acidic pH, while became aggregated under low IS at neutral pH values. It shall be noted that many reported aggregation kinetic studies were based on colloids made from prefabricated nanomaterials,24−27 which inevitably contained many agglomerated NPs due to the difficulty in dispersing them to their primary sizes. The aggregation kinetics, therefore, would be different to those well-dispersed colloids. The aggregation kinetics of NPs is controlled by the electrostatic forces and the electrosteric interferences. The magnitude of the electrosteric interference depends on the concentration of the stabilizing agent, coating thickness, the conformation and dimensions of the adsorbed double layer.17,28 From the environmental concern, the fate of NPs in an aqueous system is dependent on both particle characteristics and the complex water chemistry such as pH, ionic strength, and dissolved organic matter contents and properties, which may stabilize or agglomerate NPs, influencing their transport behavior. Quite a few studies29−32 have been conducted to investigate the effect of these influential factors, but no solid conclusion was reached, and the understanding on the fate of NPs under different environmental conditions is still very limited. Although there were a few studies on the transport of TiO2 NPs with particular reference to ionic strength and surfactants,33,34 the influence of particle morphology is essentially lacking, hence the effects of ionic strength and surfactant on the aggregation kinetics are inconclusive. This work aims to address these limitations by conducting a detailed study of the stability and aggregation kinetics of stable TiO2 NPs and investigate the influence of particle morphology under environmental-like conditions. For this purpose, two different shaped TiO2 colloids, i.e., ellipsoids and spherical NPs, were synthesized. The aggregation kinetics of well-dispersed NPs was assessed under five different stabilizing agents and four different ionic strengths. From the practical consideration, the aggregation kinetics study was conducted at neutral pH values. This detailed study shall advance the understanding in the ultimate fate of TiO2 NPs in complex environmental conditions.
■ MATERIALS AND METHODS Materials Preparation. All surfactants except Suwannee river fulvic acid (SRFA) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. SRFA was purchased from International Humic Substances Society (Atlanta, U.S.A.) while HCl and NaOH (0.01−0.1M) were purchased from Fisher Scientific for pH adjustment. Two types of titania NPs were selected from many batches of self-fabricated lots. The only precursor used in this research, i.e., 99% pure TiCl4, was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Briefly, TiO2 NPs were synthesized by a modified hydrothermal methodology, similar to the one reported by Yin et al.35 In a typical synthesis, solution 1 was made by diluting TiCl4 to 1 mol/L with 5% HCl in an ice bath. Solution 2 was prepared at different alcohol to water ratios (i.e., 1:2 ethanol/water, 1:2 methanol/water, and 1:2 acetone/water). Both solutions 1 and 2 were mixed to get 0.1 mol/L final concentration of TiCl4. Ice cooled temperature was maintained throughout the preparation process. For rutile ellipsoids synthesis, the final dispersion was stirred for 30 min with a magnetic stirrer at 45 °C temperature, whereas for spherical anatase NPs, the dispersion was treated at a temperature of 110 °C for 40 min using Teflon lined vessels in a microwave oven (MARS 5). Finally, three repetitive
washings with DI water and acetone were given to NPs by centrifugation. A 20 mL dispersion of 20 ppm spherical NPs was stabilized with different surfactants including polyethylene glycol (PEG), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS), and Suwannee river fulvic acid (SRFA). The concentrations of all surfactants were optimized for spherical NPs and similar concentrations were used for ellipsoids for all experiments. When stabilized in SRFA and sodium citrate, rutile ellipsoids and anatase spherical NPs were tested for their aggregation kinetics against different salt concentrations (NaCl, NaNO3, Ca(NO3)2, and CaCl2). An advanced X-ray diffraction spectroscopy (Bruker D-8, installed with PANalytical X’pert Pro software), Transmission electron microscope (TEM, Tecnai F-20) and Malvern Zetasizer (NanoZS90 5001) were used for NP characterization. For TEM study, rutile ellipsoids and anatase spherical NPs were stabilized with 0.3% sodium citrate and SRFA100 (i.e., the concentration of SRFA is 100 ppm). Holey carbon film TEM copper grids were purchased from Agar Scientific. In a typical preparation process, the NP sample was diluted 100 times, and a 10 μL drop of the dilute was sandwiched between two DI water drops of 50 μL. The grid was dried in a clean environment under room temperature and rinsed with DI water to remove any dirt or excessive materials. The grids for aggregation kinetics were prepared without diluting the samples, by following the same grid preparation methodology.
Time Resolved Aggregation Kinetics. Time-resolved DLS (Dynamic Light Scattering) measurements of aggregating TiO2 NPs were performed at 20 °C except for the zeta potential, which were done at 25 °C as per Malvern instructions. The scattering angle was 90° for all measurements. The concentration of the fabricated nanoparticles dispersion was measured by an atomic absorption spectrometer (AAS, Varian AA240FS), and a fixed TiO2 concentration of 20 ppm was used via dilution in all experiments. In the experiments, 1 mL of nanoparticle dispersion was mixed with different amounts of mono or divalent dispersions in a mixing vial to reach desired concentration of electrolytes. The resulting dispersion was shaken gently and transferred quickly to DLS cuvettes for the measurement. Every reading was taken at 10 s interval with the maximum of 500 readings. The effect of pH, surfactants, and zeta potential on the aggregation kinetics was studied for a period of 2 weeks. The aggregation kinetics was derived from experimentally measured particle size data. ■ RESULTS AND DISCUSSION TiO2 Characterization. The average length of rutile ellipsoids measured by TEM was 100 ± 20 nm (i.e., from randomly selected 214 ellipsoids) with an average width of 20 ± 5 nm, which gives an aspect ratio of 4.5 ± 0.3 and a hydrodynamic diameter of 55 ± 5 nm. The ellipsoids used for stability experiments were dispersed for a period over 6 months with no aggregation or agglomeration as measured by the DLS method. The spherical NPs had a core size range between 60 ± 35 nm38 and hydrodynamic diameter of 100 ± 10 nm for both citrate and SRFA100 stabilized. Figure 1a and b shows TEM
micrograph of SRFA stabilized rutile ellipsoids and spherical anatase NPs respectively, with detailed morphology shown by HRTEM in Figure 1c and d. The HRTEM micrograph of the rutile TiO2 (Figure 1c) shows lattice fringes with d-spacing of 0.248 nm, corresponding to (101) plane, and 0.324 nm, corresponding to (110) of the rutile phase. Similarly, Figure 1d shows lattice fringes with d-spacing of 0.189 nm, which
corresponds to the (200) plane, 0.352 nm corresponding to (101) plane, and 0.290 nm (121) planes of the anatase TiO2. Figure 2a and b illustrates the hydrodynamic particle size distribution of TiO2 ellipsoids and spherical NPs in water, respectively.
Impact of Surface Functionalization on the Stability of TiO2. Spherical anatase NPs were tested for their stability at different pH values in the presence of different surfactants. Results from different surfactants treatment revealed a change in size and zeta potential over a period of 2 weeks. The dispersion without surfactants was most unstable at all pH values except the highly acidic range (Figure 3a). Large agglomerates were observed at pH 5 which is near to the point of zero charge (pHzpc), i.e., pH = 5.6. Sodium citrate showed the greatest stabilization for almost all pH values except the highly acidic range (pH 1−3) because pHzpc was shifted to these values. No significant change was observed in the change of hydrodynamic size in pH 3−9 over the period of 2 weeks. The standard deviations of change in hydrodynamic diameter for three replicates show that there was inconsequential change, confirming the stability at a wide range of pH values. The control, PEG and PVP stabilized dispersion showed high aggregation rate at a pH value near to the point of zero charge (pHzpc), as seen by the large aggregates near pHzpc. The point of zero charges for sodium citrate and SRFA were 1.6 and 2.3, respectively. The zeta potential for 0.3% SDS remained on negative values from pH1 up to pH10. The size change was fairly consistent with the positive and negative charge of the particles for all the surfactants over a period of 2 weeks. Generally, the presence of negative charge on particles contributes to stabilizing nanoparticles but this is not true with 0.3 mass percentage of SDS. This may be attributed to critical micelle concentration (CMC) of SDS which is 8.2 mM (0.00082%) in water at 25 °C and above which, micelles form and all additional surfactants added to the system go to micelles.39
A comparison of the zeta potential for 2 weeks (Figure 3b, d, and f) showed no significant difference for all surfactants at all pH values except sodium citrate, which showed a slight increase in value at pH 4−7 (Figure 3f). Consistency in zeta potential after 2 weeks shows that all sites on the particle surfaces were occupied by relevant charges which stabilized the hydrodynamic diameter and zeta potential. This was also true for SRFA10 (i.e., 10 ppm of SRFA), which was not able to provide enough negative charges to cover all particles and their surfaces. In comparison, SRFA100 (i.e., 100 ppm of SRFA) provided enough concentration of charges to stabilize the dispersion. Consequently, sodium citrate (i.e., 0.3 wt %age) and SRFA100 were used for below studies.
Impact of Ionic Strength on the Aggregation of TiO2 NPs. The aggregation of nanoparticles showed a strong dependency on the ionic strength of the electrolyte dispersion. It was noted that with the addition of electrolytes, there was very slight change in pH values, i.e. ± 0.2, and the variation pH of the final dispersion was remained in the range of 6.5−7.0.
Impact on Rutile Ellipsoids. When treated with different salts, the rutile ellipsoids readily formed aggregates within 10 s of salt addition. During the first 10 s, Ca(NO3)2 gave an average aggregate diameter of 585.4 ± 22.9 and 530.3 ± 31.7 nm for sodium citrate and SRFA stabilized rutile ellipsoids, respectively. Whereas the aggregates were slightly smaller in the case of CaCl2, i.e., 531.9 ± 5.1 and 366.1 ± 4.9 nm for sodium citrate and SRFA stabilized ones, respectively. For the sodium
DOI: 10.1021/acs.est.5b05746 Environ. Sci. Technol. 2016, 50, 8462−8472
8464
citrate stabilized ellipsoids treated with NaCl and NaNO3, there was a very slight change in the initial hydrodynamic diameter with average diameters of 65.3 ± 2.1 and 59.8 ± 0.2 nm, respectively. SRFA stabilized aggregates showed an average diameter of 247.7 ± 20.2 and 190.8 ± 2.9 nm for NaCl and NaNO3, respectively (Figure 4). Clearly the initial aggregate sizes in divalent salts (Figure 4a and b) were larger than monovalent salts (Figure 4c and d). Sodium citrate stabilized NP aggregation was entirely different than SRFA stabilized as the CCC point reached quickly while for the case of SRFA stabilized, the CCC point reached slowly with addition of salts. Moreover, the salt concentration variation range was much larger in case of sodium citrate stabilized NPs as compared to SRFA stabilized (Figure 4). This is consistent with some previous reports showing quick formation of NP aggregates for different NPs.21,40,41 For example, French et al.21 reported that 4−5 nm TiO2 NPs quickly formed stable aggregates of hydrodynamic diameter of 50−60 nm in the presence of 0.0045 M NaCl at pH of 4.5. At the same pH value and 0.0165 M NaCl ionic strength, micron-sized aggregates were formed within 15 min. The time was decreased to 5 min at pH values 5.8−8.2 even at low NaCl ionic strength of 0.0084−0.0099 M. This aggregation time was 10-fold greater in an aqueous dispersion of 0.0128 M CaCl2 and pH of 4.8. In another study Chen et al.36 showed that divalent salts CaCl2 and MgCl2 gave much higher aggregate growth rate of alginate-coated hematite NPs than that of monovalent NaCl. This process of aggregation was controlled by the thermodynamics where NPs reduced their energies to form large aggregates. Figure 5 shows selected TEM micrographs of all salts used, which illustrates clearly that there were large aggregate size and structural difference in the presence of monovalent (Figure 5a,b) and divalent (Figure 5c,d) salts.
As shown in Figure 6, there is a general trend of destabilizing NP with the increase of salt concentration. For mono valence salts, the sodium citrate stabilized ellipsoids showed better stability with a critical coagulation concentration of 1380 ± 10 mM NaCl (Figure 6a), whereas for SRFA, the CCC was reduced to 790 mM NaCl (Figure 6a). Similarly NaNO3 gave the CCC of 238 mM for sodium citrate stabilized NPs, which was much higher than SRFA stabilized NPs with the CCC of 72 mM (Figure 6b). The divalent ion behaved quite different from the monovalent salts. In the presence of Ca(NO3)2, the CCC was 16 mM (Figure 6c) for sodium citrate stabilized ellipsoids, which was reduced to 8.9 mM for SRFA stabilized NPs. In the presence of CaCl2, the CCC was observed as 10.7 mM and 4.2 mM for sodium citrate stabilized ellipsoids (Figure 6d) and SRFA stabilized NPs. While these results were similar in the general trend with monovalent salts, the CCC values were much smaller, indicating that TiO2 NPs were more prone to be destabilized by the presence of divalent salts. The sticking efficiencies in the presence of monovalent salts showed a minimal rise as compared to divalent salts. It might be due to the fact that the degree of Debye−Hückel charge screening in monovalent salts was relatively smaller than divalent salts. This difference in CCCs was mainly because that Ca2+ ions had high efficiency to form complexes with citrate and fulvic acid.42 It was noted that the CCCs of both SRFA and sodium citrate stabilized ellipsoids in the presence of divalent ions were much lower than the CCCs of monovalent salts. It is well documented that the dominant interacting mechanism is the interaction of Ca2+ ions with carboxyl groups in citrate, and the bridging complex with fulvic acid and humics characteristics are important from complex formation.36,43−46 Both of these reactions basically neutralized the stabilization effect hence
DOI: 10.1021/acs.est.5b05746 Environ. Sci. Technol. 2016, 50, 8462−8472
8465
causing quick destabilization of NPs. Moreover, this inequality of CCCs is most likely due to the lower tendency of monovalent cations to form complexes as compared to higher propensity of divalent cations, hence having higher CCC values. When the concentration of mono or divalent salt is increased gradually, the amount of charge screening increases, allowing an increase in aggregation kinetics. This type of aggregation is called reaction-limited aggregation. When the concentration of mono or divalent salts is very high, the charge of stabilized NP is fully screened, eliminating the energy barrier between NPs. Such an aggregation is defined as diffusion-limited aggregation where the aggregation kinetics approached the maximum and is independent of the salt concentration. The CCC is actually the intersection of the crossover point between both reaction and diffusion limited aggregation points. At high concentrations of mono and divalent salts, the overall charge of TiO2 NPs is totally screened, and the energy barrier between NPs is eliminated. Impact on Anatase Spherical NPs. The overall roundness of NPs can be determined with a parameter called shape factor
(α) which is defined as “the ratio of the surface area of a nonspherical nanoparticle (So) to that of a spherical nanoparticle (S), where both of the nanoparticles have identical volume, i.e., α = So/S.47 Due to many fluctuations in the aggregation behaviour of rutile ellipsoids as described above, round anatase NPs with a shape factor of 0.9 or above were selected. The aggregation behaviour of round particles was different from the ellipsoids (Figures 5 and 7). For spherical TiO2 NPs, the results obtained from three measurements were more consistent, as shown by the small standard deviation values in Figure 8. In the presence of divalent salts, the agglomeration results were similar between spherical and ellipsoid TiO2, where the CCC values were consistently lower for SRFA stabilized dispersions. However, for monovalent salt, the CCC has shown smaller values for sodium citrate stabilized dispersions. For instance, the CCCs were 900 and 1025 mM, respectively, for sodium citrate and SRFA stabilized NPs in the presence of NaCl. Similarly in the presence of NaNO3, the CCC values were 90 and 115 mM,
DOI: 10.1021/acs.est.5b05746 Environ. Sci. Technol. 2016, 50, 8462−8472
8466
respectively, for sodium citrate and SRFA stabilized NPs. A summary of the CCC values is provided in Table 1.
■ DISCUSSION Aggregation of TiO2 Nanomaterials in the Presence of Sodium Chloride. The aggregation kinetics of TiO2 NP in NaCl varied with the type of stabilizing agents. Results for sodium citrate stabilized titania ellipsoids reproduced in Figure 6a were in accordance with DLVO theory and gave a CCC of 1380 mM NaCl. This result was beyond the expectations but sodium citrate stabilized spheres also resulted in a CCC value of 790 mM (Figure 6a and Table 1). However, the CCC for SRFA stabilized spherical NP was a bit higher than the CCC values ellipsoids (Figures 6a, 8a, and Table 1). There was an obvious difference in sticking efficiencies and
the initial particle size of both types of SRFA stabilized nanomaterials. A change in NaCl concentration showed an obvious difference in the aggregates structure with a change of particle morphology (Figures 6a, 8a and Table 1). This observation is consistent with the observation made by Huynh et. al (2011) while treating spherical citrate-coated Ag NP with NaCl concentrations.44 The current results show that sodium citrate stabilized ellipsoids have more stability against NaCl as
compared to SRFA, while sodium citrate stabilized spherical NPs showed lower CCC values compared to SRFA. The stability and aggregation differences for two different shapes, i.e., spherical and ellipsoids are mainly because of the arrangement of stabilizing ions and polymer chains. These packing arrangements in reaction and diffusion limited regimes for ellipsoids and spherical NP curvatures are shape specific and give distinctiveness to each type.48
As shown schematically in Figure 9, spherical TiO2 NPs have higher curvature as compared to the TiO2 ellipsoids, which would alter the physical packing of the stabilizing agent, resulting in a more compact layer of stabilizing agent for spherical NP as compared to more extended layers for the ellipsoids. This arrangement of the stabilizing agent would produce higher electrosteric interactions on the curvatures of ellipsoids, giving them enhanced stability at reaction limited regime. While at diffusion limited regime, the ellipsoids gave more stabilization because of higher physical packing with larger amounts of cations. Nanorods have been proven to have higher physical packing hindrances as compared to small packing density in nanospheres.49 Thus, electrosteric interactions at reaction limited regime and physical hindrances arrangements of the stabilizing agent in diffusion limited regime are considered as a plausible
DOI: 10.1021/acs.est.5b05746 Environ. Sci. Technol. 2016, 50, 8462−8472
8467
mechanism for the morphological effect on aggregation. So it is likely that the observed behavior of ellipsoids is due to steric interactions for the particles having larger aspect ratios. In one study on colloidal hemeatite, Boxall et al.50 showed that dicarboxylic organic acids provided steric effects and promoted aggregation.
It is well documented in the literature that the nanoparticles stabilized with carboxylic acids were more homogenized and had more negative surface charge as compared to those synthesized in water alone.51 So sodium citrate could influence more on the electrosteric effect in case of ellipsoids with higher aspect ratios than spherical NPs. In both cases of SRFA and
DOI: 10.1021/acs.est.5b05746 Environ. Sci. Technol. 2016, 50, 8462−8472
8468
sodium citrate, all NP contained net negative charges, which were repelled by the negative counterions on the nanoparticles
surface. This repulsion effect was believed to be stronger in case of ellipsoids due to increased surface area as compared to counterion effect of spherical NPs. Ellipsoids stabilized with SRFA exhibited an aggregation behavior quite similar to that for SRFA stabilized spherical NP (Figures 6a, 8a, and Table 1). There was no obvious increase in the CCC both for ellipsoids and spherical NP stabilized with SRFA. SRFA may enhance particle stability by promoting electrosteric repulsion. The initial particle size of nanomaterial did not increase until the concentration of NaCl reached 500 mM for SRFA and 1250 mM for sodium citrate stabilized ellipsoids (Figure 4c and d). In comparison, this growth started from 500 mM of NaCl for sodium citrate and SRFA stabilized spherical NP (Figure 4e and f). These results clearly reveal the influence of aspect ratio, which enhanced the stability of NPs under the same dispersion conditions. It is understood that synthetic or natural stabilizing agents would restrain electron transfer reactions as they reduced the accessibility of the available surface area to stop reactions and increase stability.23,52,53
Another reason for the stability of SRFA stabilized NP is the hydrophobicity of FA.54 As per IHSS proton-binding study of the functional group charge densities, the phenol-carboxylic ratio of FA was 0.25 with a molecular weight of 500−2000 g/ mol.54 In this study, NPs stabilized with SRFA was due to its greater hydrophobicity55 and stronger steric repulsion,23 which resisted more to the addition of salts irrespective of the shape. TiO2 ellipsoids with SRFA provided greater stability as compared to spherical NPs under similar conditions. Erhayem and Sohn56 revealed that the adsorption of SRFA to nano-TiO2 surface was dependent on ionic strength regardless of the pH of media. With an increase in ionic strength, the SRFA would become more twisted and compact. This twisting might give more nanoparticles surface area to be occupied by
DOI: 10.1021/acs.est.5b05746 Environ. Sci. Technol. 2016, 50, 8462−8472
8469
the SRFA, giving a secondary stability. Therefore, the amount of adsorption of SRFA on the surface of TiO2 NPs is highly dependent on the ionic strength. This twisting of the SRFA would explain the higher stability of ellipsoids as compared to spherical NPs because of more surface area of ellipsoids. At acidic pH, the TiO2 surface has positive charges so cations give a bridging effect between positively charged TiO2 surface and negatively charged SRFA, again imparting a secondary stability. Although this imparted stability loses its magnitude with increasing ionic strength, it might be a factor for the increased stability of ellipsoids due to increased surface area. Aggregation of TiO2 Nanomaterials in the Presence of Sodium Nitrate. The sodium citrate and SRFA stabilized titania nanomaterials behaved like NaCl aggregation when treated with NaNO3. The CCC for citrate-coated nanoparticles in NaNO3 was 72 mM (Figure 6b and Table 1) for SRFA stabilized ellipsoids which increased to 110 mM for spherical NP (Figure 6b and Table 1). There was a drop in CCC, from a value of 238 mM for titania ellipsoids (Figure 6b and Table 1) to 90 mM NaNO3 (Figure 8b and Table 1), which was similar to the value measured in case of NaCl. These CCC values were far less than NaCl CCC values although both salts were monovalent. As compared to NaCl, sodium citrate provided a degree of steric stability to the ellipsoids. The starting hydrodynamic size of the sodium citrate stabilized nanomaterials in NaNO3, just like in NaCl, followed a decreasing trend with increasing electrolyte concentration initially (Figures 6b and 8b). It was noted that the aggregate sizes were higher in high concentrations of NaNO3 than in similar concentrations of NaCl, suggesting that the effect of stabilizing agents was enhanced in NaNO3 than in NaCl. Moreover, in the presence of NO3
−, an open fractal structure was observed for the aggregated NPs (Figure 7b and d); however, Cl− gave closed fractal structures (Figure 7a and c), which are the characteristics of aggregation under unfavorable circumstances. So NO3 − always gave larger and open structures in all the cases and Cl− gave smaller aggregate structures (Figure 5). Different CCC values for differently stabilized NPs and for NaCl or NaNO3 clearly shows that the electrolyte anion have somehow very important role and it was not a ligand only. The role of anion was further confirmed by obvious differences in the aggregation of sodium citrate stabilized NPs in NaCl and NaNO3. The difference in the CCC and aggregation behavior was not dependent on ion size, because the hydrated radius of Cl− at 3.32 Å and NO−3 at 3.35 Å57 are quite close and might not be able to give much difference in behavior. It might be that NO−3 made gel-like complexes with SRFA and sodium citrate. The CCC values of two types of anions reveal that anion effect depends on the type of electrolyte. The stability of TiO2 ellipsoids and spherical NPs were affected at very low concentrations of Cl− and NO3− for divalent salts while huge amount of Cl− was required to destabilize both types of NPs in case of NaCl. As Ca+ always form a gel-like aggregate36 and NO3 forms open fractal branched structures, Ca(NO3)2 make larger aggregates as compared to monovalent salts or divalent Ca+ with Cl−. This is well confirmed from the sticking efficiencies, where monovalent electrolytes gave more stability with higher CCC values. The combined effect of the gel-like aggregates effect of Ca+ with the open fractal structures of NO3
− would be the possible reason for larger aggregate size and lower CCC values for Ca(NO3)2. The aggregation state in all cases is related to the overall surface area, adsorption of anion and sorbate surface exposure. The CCC results showed that the
greater the attraction of anions by TiO2 surface, the lower is the stability and vice versa.
Aggregation of TiO2 Nanomaterials in the Presence of Calcium Nitrate. Ca(NO3)2 showed aggregation behavior which was quite in line with NaNO3 (Table 1). No changes were observed between CCC values of both types of NPs but these CCC values are far less than NaNO3 CCC value, which was attributed to Ca2+ because of its quick screen of surface charge by divalent ions. This enhancement in aggregation might be due to the compression of the electrical diffused double layer on TiO2 NP surface as a result of chelation between NP surface and Ca2+. The results show that the CCC for the SRFA stabilized TiO2 NPs (either ellipsoids or spherical) was at least an order of magnitude higher than sodium citrate coated NPs. Both types of TiO2 NPs either coated with SRFA or sodium citrate had negative zeta potential values. With the addition of divalent calcium cations, the zeta potential of stabilized NPs decreased. It is well documented in the literature that Ca2+ forms a complex with organic matter stabilized hematite NPs, which neutralized the negative surface charge of the NPs.36 In the presence of divalent Ca2+, the same mechanism governs the destabilization of both types of NPs. SRFA imparted the negative charge on the surface of both types of TiO2 NPs. These imparted negative charges made complex with Ca2+ to destabilize the NP dispersion even with little amounts of the divalent salt.
Aggregation of TiO2 Nanomaterials in the Presence of Calcium Chloride. The aggregation behavior observed in CaCl2 was similar to that observed in NaCl but the NP started to aggregate at a lower concentration of CaCl2. The stability of the SRFA stabilized nanomaterials in CaCl2 was obviously different from that in NaCl, as divalent cations quickly changed the aggregation stage. The ellipsoids either stabilized by sodium citrate or SRFA showed a better magnitude of stability as compared to spherical NP mainly due to the greater surface area. This clearly illustrates the effect of shape on the stability of NPs. The high charge screening efficiency of Ca2+ ions for the nanomaterials could be the possible aggregation mechanisms along with the specific interaction of nanomaterials, Ca2+ ions and stabilizing agents.58
Huynh and Chen44 considered the interparticle bridging of NPs by interaction of humic acid and Ca2+ ions as the main reason for aggregation. They emphasized that polymer coated NPs had more stability as compared to citrate coated NPs in the presence of monovalent and divalent ions. This is more likely due to the electrosteric stability induced by large chain polymers. The sticking of SRFA molecules imparted additional stability to the NPs in the presence of low concentrations of ions. But when the concentration was high, the intermolecular bridging induced by SRFA gave enhanced aggregation. In a short summary, this study showed that the surfactant, ionic strength, and morphology of TiO2 NPs affected their aggregation kinetics significantly. SRFA stabilized NPs were relatively more stable than sodium citrate stabilized NPs, mainly due to the electrosteric repulsion by the SRFA molecules. The NP morphology greatly influenced the sticking efficiency and crystal structure, which altered the aggregation kinetics. TiO2 ellipsoids proved more resistant to aggregation than spherical NPs against different Ca2+ and Na+ salts at similar concentrations. Salt concentrations would change the sticking efficiency between individual NPs and NP-substrate surfaces. It is considered that the aggregation kinetics was
DOI: 10.1021/acs.est.5b05746 Environ. Sci. Technol. 2016, 50, 8462−8472
8470
mainly due to Ca2+ and Na+ cations, but CO3 − and Cl− anions may also have their impacts. As the CCC values for both types of NPs were greater than typical environmental related concentrations of mono and divalent salt concentrations, it is likely that TiO2 NPs are highly mobile in natural environments. Moreover natural environments have fulvic and humic acids in abundance, which would act as surfactants and further increase the stability of TiO2 NPs, resulting in a potential high mobility of these NPs. However, due to the complexities in real soil matrix, which would have different complex ions and natural organic matters, understanding the ultimate fate of engineered nanoparticles is still a big challenge. Clearly there is still a strong need of further studies to establish the influences of other environmental constituents, such as natural organic matters, humic acids, and different metals on the NP stability, aggregation kinetics, and mobility, as well as the effect of particle material and phase contents.

metadata.abstractText: Nanoparticle morphology is expected to play a significant role in the stability, aggregation behavior, and ultimate fate of engineered nanomaterials in natural aquatic environments. The aggregation kinetics of ellipsoidal and spherical titanium dioxide (TiO2) nanoparticles (NPs) under different surfactant loadings, pH values, and ionic strengths were investigated in this study. The stability results revealed that alteration of surface charge was the stability determining factor. Among five different surfactants investigated, sodium citrate and Suwannee river fulvic acid (SRFA) were the most effective stabilizers. It was observed that both types of NPs were more stable in monovalent salts (NaCl and NaNO3) as compared with divalent salts (Ca(NO3)2 and CaCl2). The aggregation of spherical TiO2 NPs demonstrated a strong dependency on the ionic strength regardless of the presence of mono or divalent salts; while the ellipsoids exhibited a lower dependency on the ionic strength but was more stable. This work acts as a benchmark study toward understanding the ultimate fate of stabilized NPs in natural environments that are rich in Ca(CO3)2, NaNO3, NaCl, and CaCl2 along with natural organic matters. ■ INTRODUCTION TiO2 is a multipurpose material widely used in nanoparticulate form. TiO2 nanoparticles (NPs) are routinely used in products like sun creams, cosmetics, paints, self-cleaning dispersions, textiles, sports equipment, solar cells, and wastewater treatment devices, as well as acting as additives for enhanced oil recovery,. Its unique properties give it an increased demand in different industries but at the same time causes increasing environmental concerns. It is understood that the migration behavior, toxicity, and bioavailability of NPs are governed by their physicochemical properties such as shape, size, surface area, agglomeration state, zeta potential, and surface chemistry. In the past decade, the aggregation kinetics of different NPs has been extensively investigated. As TiO2 NPs have the tendency to aggregate and coalesce into big particles, which is undesirable for most of the applications, their colloidal stability investigation becomes important. Most of the physicochemical properties of NPs are related to their behaviors in dispersions including the reactions at the particle−liquid interface. To fully evaluate the environmental implications, the mobility and risks of such NPs, the knowledge regarding their interaction with different media constituents, and the aggregation kinetics are essential. Several factors are responsible for NPs aggregation as studied by different scientists. First, the surface charge of the NPs greatly influences their solubility and hence the stability. Surface charge results in either attractive (positive−negative interaction) or repulsive (similar charge interactions) energies, which depends on the pH, temperature, and the concentration and type of the electrolyte in the medium. The presence of electrolytes in the medium would alter the stability and agglomeration state of NP dispersions. Second, the concentration of the NP precursors, polymers, surfactants, and the temperature would alter the overall stability of dispersions. Water or other molecules could interact with NPs and alter their crystal structures. Zinc sulfide (ZnS) NP is a good example as reported by Zhang et al. (2003), where 3 nm ZnS NP containing around 700 atoms rearranged their crystal structures after interaction with water to form more ordered bulk structure. Guzman and co-workers showed a pHzpc (i.e., pH at point of zero charge) dependence of titania NPs while French et al. observed the influence of ionic strength (IS), on the aggregation kinetics of 50−60 nm TiO2 agglomerates (with 5 nm primary size) at low IS. Similarly surface charge and zeta-potential have a strong correlation with the aggregation kinetics of ZnO NPs.
